reviewText: This is an interesting tale about a mediaeval christian religious practice (anchorites) that takes place in England during the period when the shift from paganism to christianity took place.  The story focuses on an innocent young girl who chooses to become an anchoress and how she is treated by the church, the local villagers, and the local reeve (estate manager for a lord) and her innocence and mixed pagan/christian faith.  It is a slow moving story, but it is a rich one.
summary: Innocence and Faith in a Time of Change
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is very good and does some good work in representing both the Catholic Church's viewpoint of women and the feminine in God or the lack thereof in regard to Christianity.  It also does a fair job of representing some pagan views.  This puts everything into a down to earth (no pun intended) perspective of religions view of real life (or lack thereof). It demonstrates many problems that have still not been dealt with by western churches.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I think it would have helped me if I had had a strong interest in the period of time the story took place (Middle Ages?).  It was a physically unattractive movie, and the plot seemed chaotic.  Also, I had bought the movie because of my interest in the young actress, Natalie Morse, but she spent most of the movie in an underground cave.  I don't recommend this film.

reviewText: I found this movie rather tedious.At times it was really hard to see what was going on.The black and white might have appealed if it had been done better.The scenes in the rain were the hardest to watch.The times this was supposed to be in were very dark and hard times.The idea that a young girl would voluntarily chose such a path are abhoring.Priests, had way to much power over people in those times.The church ruled and kept people under control that way.If you can sit through it, it could be worth watching.Anchoresses and their roles, are not often dealt with in modern society.I have only read about them in books.This was the first time I saw it broached in a movie.

reviewText: It was Ok. I believe the theme of the story was excellent. No doubt at that period in time in Feudal Europe, there was a lot of suspicions about the way people displayed themselves. There was also a lot of ignorance as well as stupidity.  As good example of this was when the Mother who hard a difficult time accepting the mixture of Religion as well as local witchcraft ended up being murdered by the towns people by being thrown down a well as they considered her a witch. The Bishop as well as the local Priest added to more ignorance. The acting was relatively OK. The Black and White exposure actually added a lot of interest. Many thanks for your attention.
Title: N/A

reviewText: After reading all the wonderful reviews on this film I purchased it and my husband and I watched it.  It was just awful!  It made no sense, jumps scenes constantly and the dialogue is rather difficult to understand.  It is black and white and situated in the most dismal place.  Grey, rocky just plain ugly.  Save your money and your time.  It is a real waste.  We are religious people and had a good idea of what Anchoress' are but this  movie did nothihg for the subject.

reviewerName: The Movie Guy "Movies from A to Z"
reviewText: The film is in black and white symbolic of the fact color photography wasn't available in Medieval times. Christine Carpenter (Natalie Morse) is entranced and obsessed with the Virgin Mary. To the dismay of her pagan herbalist mother (Brenda Bertin) and Reeve (Gene Bervoets) who had designs on her, she opts to become an anchoress, being walled up in confinement.  Christine quickly becomes a celebrity offering her divine advice through a window of hope.The priest (Christopher Eccleston) while initially happy becomes irate over Christine's disobedience and visions contrary to teachings. Christine sees Mary's hair as being braided as wheat dressed in a red robe, like an apple. There is a clash between the pagan and Christian worlds.The film is riddled with symbolism and it is an art film. It is not Ingmar Bergman good, but if you like that type of film without the subtitles, check this one out.It was not my cup of tea.
summary: EMBRACE YOUR BODY AND HOLD IT FAST
Title: N/A
